reviewText: Once again BBC dishes out a classy period soap opera. The production values are high, and the acting is good. Every episode is a mini-melodrama where some character gets into trouble or has to make a decision, with the smaller problems resolved and the larger ones carried on. Viewers' heartstrings are constantly and carefully tugged.Episode after episode, Miss Lane and her former boyfriend Sir Timothy dance around whether to carry their relationship to a different level or end it entirely. Actually, they decide to end it repeatedly, they just don't carry through--even though they've been having this debate since Sir Timothy got married over four years ago. The feckless Lark Rise housewife Arliss has been pregnant for the entire Season 1 so far (I'm partway through the last episode). And there are other issues that seem dragged out for no particular reason.Some episodes don't hold together. For example, the one where a needlepointed tapestry over 50 years old is found sitting on a grave in the churchyard wrapped in a thin layer of newspaper. It's supposedly been there, outdoors, for 50 years, but, hello? it hasn't gotten moldy. It gives several characters the same spooky dream, except for the poor man who found it, who fantasizes about making what is for him a fortune from selling it--but then, he inexplicably gives it up. The specter never actually appears. The narration promises at the beginning that this incident will "shed light on Miss Lane's past"--but considering the tapestry proves to have nothing to do with her, it doesn't. A fizzle, in other words.Episodes also show the unevenness of different script writers, with Sir Timothy's wife's character ranging from naive and silly (at times hysterical), to intentionally catty, to wronged but resolute--then back to something else. The actors' accents range from Irish to English North country, and are sometimes present and sometimes not.Lark Rise to Candleford really is a fine period soap opera, just . . . a lot of the time it's nothing more. I recommend taking it in rather small doses, as what is charming once every two or three evenings becomes somewhat annoying every evening.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: great series one that makes you laugh and cry while also being thought provoking about social and cultural issues that are true even today

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: This series has a breath taking cinematic character and a feeling for the quieter dramas of human life as it is more often lived, against the background of worldwide change and generation by generation.  Though few of us actually shape the "big picture," our lives and those of the people around us definitely shape the track upon which these events occur.  Like the effects of drops of water on the contours of the earth, our attitudes, willingness to cooperate, even just what we choose to purchase or not, has an impact on what the world becomes.  It may take a while--though with mass communication how long it takes has significantly shortened--but our individual choices shape history in ways we will probably never know.There is an intensity brought to the everyday lives of these characters by some very superb acting; so much is this so that one has only to view one episode to have opinions about them, about their behaviors and about what they "ought" to do.  The restrained passion between Sir Timothy and the postmistress, Dorcas, are wonderful, with so much conveyed by looks and polite behavior that the story is virtually before the viewer without its having to be blatantly related.  We are so certain we understand the unspoken drama that finding out the details is actually a surprise.The stunningly beautiful Lady Adelaide is superb as the over bred and well born wife in love with her husband, of whom she suspects an at least emotional unfaithfulness with the postmistress but about which she feels incapable of dealing effectively.  Her efforts to understand and fit into the life of her husband, a rural aristocrat, remind one of the classic filmRebeccawhere there is a similar "blundering around" without guidence, though in this case the lady actually is a "Lady."  The difference between the expectations of urban and rural roles is dramatized very well in this single character.  Expecting a life of urban social obligations including the theater, balls, formal dinners, etc. in the competitive and cut-throat social milieu of London and for which she would be more than adequately prepared, she is instead thrust into the more primitive social obligations of dependant tenant farmers and day laborers and local tradesmen, with none of whose every day realities she is even remotely familiar.  Though we don't always approve of her respones to the situation, we can certainly sympathize with her situation.The sisters Pratt are the epitome of those with a tenuous hold on their place in society as "gentlewomen" without independent means who must make their own living as seamstresses.  Their secrets hold them hostage to the prejudices of society and shape their attitudes towards others.  They assume an arrogance toward people of lesser means, an obsequious manner toward those of greater and make every effort to "get the goods" on anyone of equal rank to have ammunition against them in case of need.  All of this makes them less than admirable individuals, yet their fear of falling into the lower ranks of society by virtue of their father's character is not without foundation.  Yet it is precisely their perpetuation of the prejudice and unfairness of their society that puts them in peril.  Many of their activities, however, make them more comedic figures than sinister ones, which gives them a certain grace despite themselves.  Their tendency not only to overdress but to do so identically, makes them seem a bit like a pair of court jesters!Just as with the Pratt sisters, Caroline, the multipara and expectant "lost cause" is delightful.  Her totally illogical approach to life and her optimism--if not totally realistic--are wonderful.  Her situation is virtually untenable, but she keeps going despite it.  If some of her schemes don't materialize, it is not without trying.  That she drinks is not surprising.  Certainly her alternative is dispair, depression, and probably suicide.  Her explanation for being in debtors court is brilliant and true, if not entirely honest, and leaves one thinking of ones own credit card debt and financial situation.  Her sense of being "untouchable" after winning her case, leading her to enlarge her indebtedness should remind us of ourselves.  Twister, the lazy husband of Queenie the beekeeper, is another comedic character.  One senses that his youthful self was probably far less pleasant, but that time and perhaps dementia have mellowed him out a lot.  Some of the most poignant scenes involve him and his wife.The rigidity of social class structure and the expectations made on the various strata of it are also made apparent through the expectations of the two villages.  The "upper class" town of Candleford attempts to defend its privileges and looks to the future with greater acceptance, while the working class town of Lark Rise attempts to demand its rights under the law and fights fiercely for respect of its simple dignity.  Having been on the short end of the stick for decades, if not centuries, it looks upon the approach of change with suspicion.  Yet beneath all of this rivalry, when the chips are down, each village comes to the aid of the other.A wonderful group of people to spend time with.
summary: A lovey community in which to spend a little time.

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: LARK RISE TO CANDLEFORD is The Beeb's answer to such dramas as "Little House on the Prairie" and "Road to Avonlea".  Based on several autobiographical volumes from Flora Thompson, the series is a gentle echo of a long-vanished time when community spirit and family values weren't so hard to come by as they seem to be now.Concerned about the future of their eldest daughter Laura (Olivia Hallinan) in their small village of Lark Rise, Robert and Emma Timmins (Brendan Coyle and Claudie Blakley) arrange for the girl to go to work at the post office in the neighbouring market town of Candleford.  The post office and adjoining forge are both run with acute precision by Emma's cousin, Dorcas Lane (Julia Sawalha), one of the town's leading personalities.  As Laura literally steps into an entirely new world, she learns all about the lives of the Candleford residents on her daily mail run.Spinster sisters Pearl and Ruby Pratt (Matilda Ziegler and Victoria Hamilton) run the town's most fashionable shop and are as nosey and snobbish as they are full of long-buried family scandals.  Caroline Arless (Dawn French) from Lark Rise is always getting into trouble with debt-collectors because of her reckless spending habits, whilst Laura's childhood romance with Caroline's son Alf (John Dagleish) soon evaporates because of Laura's busy schedule.  The twin communities of Lark Rise and Candleford are connected not only through the post office, but by local magistrate Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) and his wife Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant).  Their marriage is troubled by Adelaide's feverish quest to have a baby and the unresolved adolescent courtship of Dorcas and Timothy, which Adelaide increasingly regards as a direct threat to her happiness.The performances are perfection.  Her earlier roles in "Pride & Prejudice" and "Cranford" notwithstanding, who would have ever pegged Julia Sawalha ("clinically-depressed budgerigar" Saffy from "Absolutely Fabulous") as the prim leading lady of a weekly period drama series?  Dorcas Lane is the pivot from which most of the drama unfolds in this series and she more than holds her own as one of the great heroines.  I adore her.  Brendan Coyle's Robert Timmins is the stoic, loving father figure but the writing also explores his faults and shortcomings with great skill.  "Vicar of Dibley" fans will be pleasantly surprised with the onscreen reunion of Dawn French and Liz Smith - who plays Dorcas' crusty old housekeeper Zillah.  You'll no doubt find your own favourite characters.Four DVD set with 10 episodes plus a 30-minute "Making Of" featurette.  Sheer bliss for lovers of costume/period drama.
summary: addictive period drama that's perfect for the whole family
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Lark Rise To Candleford must be viewed to appreciate it's perfection! Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: This is series based on three novels published in the 1940s about a young woman and the families in two particular towns. The stories are set in the late 1800s, just before the turn of the century. The novels are semi-autobiographical, so they have an honest appeal to them.The events that occur are not the earth shattering and ground breaking instances that most major series are filled with. Instead the stories revolve around everyday life in these two hamlets. Lark Rise is conservative, smaller, and more remote. Candleford is a town on the rise with influences from near and far. We see these influences with such subtle hints as the unveiling of the latest Parisian fashions for example. Several of the stories deal with family issues, debts, and work. Troubles that still ring true even today.There are some terrific actors and actresses that one might recognize from Cranford, Downton Abbey, and other top notch British drama series. The roles are played well with an emphasis on subtlety, instead of the more dramatic performances in series such as Downton. The acting and the sets remind me a lot more of Cranford, despite the 40 or 50 year gap in their time periods.Though the series starts with young Laura as the apparent main character, she acts more as a foil to the other various characters. It is a slow paced series, and many of the supporting characters have episodes focused on them. It's all very well done and there is no sense to trying to fit too much in. Often the scenes and episodes can be rather sparse and quiet.The show went on for four seasons (series as they are known in the UK) and was sadly not renewed for a fifth, despite impressive ratings. Whether you watch on instant streaming or on DVD, the show is very good and is a nice change of pace from some of the more dramatic pieces out there. Which is not to say there isn't drama! But it's definitely a more toned down series. If you get through episode three and aren't hooked, then you probably won't want to continue watching. But if you are like me, by episode three you start to see the real genius here and want to watch more.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Endearing characters, good acting, good writing. Sometimes the sound quality and/or the British accent make it a little hard to understand, but that's a minor quibble. It's not "Downton Abbey," but it's very good.

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Lark Rise and Candleford are two charming little towns in England, one close to the soil, the other more prosperous and inclined to adapt to modernity. The one thing that unites them is that most of the main characters have been to the local community college to study Psychology and all have apparently been reading back issues of Psychology Today. This enables them to do an unusual amount of introspection and gives them an abilty to articulate their feelings an a way that would make them proud in any 1990's support group. Another oddity is dialogue that has a generous springling of 21st century colloquialisms which sound a bit off key in Victorian England. In spite of this, Lark Rise to Candlford is very engaging and Julia Sawalha presides over it all with warmth and good humor.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: A delightful series complete with favorite actors from lots of period movie favorites.  Characters were enjoyable as was the plot. I was hooked from the first episode. I know some have commented that it was slow, but I felt it moved about the same pace as similar movie favorites (likeCranford).  If you're very particular about what you watch - stick with this season and skip season 2 and 3 which decrease in believability and quality. Season One can stand on it's own as enjoyable entertainment.

reviewText: Oh my! What can I say. I love, love, love Lark Rise to Candleford. I love to watch british movies, but this is so enjoyable. I could not wait to see each season. My absolute favorite is Season 1 and 2. But the others are good too. I was so sorry that it did not continue. Hopefully, someone will make a movie. I strongly recommend this series. If you love comedy, romance, drama,some mystery and tears you will love this.

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I was searching amazon for a new period drama, found this one, and decided to purchase it based on the reviews and the quality of actors -- including Julia Sawalha (Pride & Prejudice and Cranford), Brendan Coyle (North & South), Ben Miles (The Forsyte Saga), Dawn French and Claudie Blakely.  I was not disappointed.  It was absolutely fabulous and I didn't want it to end.  In fact, I've watched it a second time since purchasing it a month ago.  I cannot wait until they release series two in the U.S. (it's already available in Europe). If you're thinking of buying it, don't hesitate.  It's well worth the $42, ranking up there with P&P, N&S, Cranford, The Forsyte Saga, Sense & Sensibility (Emma Thompson version, which I happen to like better than the recent Andew Davies version), Emma (Gwyneth Paltrow version), Persuasion (Amanda Root version), etc. (I love period drama and own just about every one released).  What better way to spend a rainy Sunday afternoon?  Enjoy!
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: After viewing many intense and "nail biting" detective/mystery shows (e.g., "Luther ", "Murphy's Law",  "Murdock" ,  "Touch of Frost", "Midsomer Murders"  et al), this very good BBC presentation on  four (4) discs with ten (10) episodes that are about an hour in length  , gave me a great deal of respite from all of the mayhem and blood that I that I tend to view.  In this season one (1) of "Lark Rise to Candleford" we are introduced to some very gentle folks in the gorgeous and beautifully filmed Oxfordshire countryside in the 19th century.  This series (at least in Volume one) is very well acted and directed with stories that are easy to view--no blood or violence, just people living their lives in some very gentle times. The people are made up of mainly farm-workers and folks that can build "things" with their hands.There are two (2) communities, Lark Rise and Candleford with Lark Rise being more "countrified" and Candleford being more "citified" having a post office and a little more "bustle" to it.  The stories heroine, Laura Timmins comes from a small and loving family in Lark Rise to Candleford to work and learn how to be a post office mistress. There she finds scandals, secrets, jealousies, feuds, hidden loves, pettiness,etc.  Her adventures in both communities and with the fascinating inhabitants therein are what make up the stories of this presentation.  All in all, I enjoyed visiting some very gentle times that are shown in this program
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: If you like British period shows, this one is the one you want to see. You will not stop at one episode or one season. The story surrounds the postmistress who lives in the town where the more well-to-do people live. Outside of the town is a hamlet called Larkrise and there is a constant struggle just to survive. How the rich and the poor intermingle is fascinating and will give you a glimpse into what life was like for both groups.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: English country life could never have been as poetic, pictorial, and enchanting as this dramatization of the lives of those living in and around the two 1880's towns of Lark Rise and Candleford. Even the DVD's music puts a sanguine sugarcoating on the period. All of this is to the delight of the viewer of this masterfully done TV series sure to endear any North American who has a tender video heart toward Victorian Britain. Perhaps, consider it a British mutation of "Little House on the Prairie" or "The Waltons."This set of 4 DVDs, 10 episodes totaling 582 minutes, is actually a 9 1/2+ hour saga (continuing panorama of human relationship) of the commoner village and the more sophisticated Candleford. The short 8-mile separation allows for much intermingling, bigotry, conflict, forbidden love, political and economic interaction. It is not a family saga, not a nobility bloodline dramatization, but a saga of struggles and lifestyles of different kinds of personalities, each caught in their own born-into world, and interacting with another different, and not always understood, class of folk.Darling Laura Timmins (Olivia Hallinan), oldest child of a Lark Rise family, is sent off to Candleford to learn the trade of postmistress. She is the spark caught between the two towns (sometimes world's different.) Her mentor, Dorcas (Julia Sawalha), has a personal secret. There is the expected, token-gentry, rich, Squire family, Sir Timothy (Ben Miles)& Lady Adelaide (Oliva Grant). The rest of the regular cast (at least 20 appearing in all 10 episodes) is an assortment of either the die-hard, disheveled, working class or the Candleford higher class, but yet short of nobility range. It is the individuals that make this spectacular (or fill in your own highest superlative.)One episode travels into the next with carryover from earlier material. If you have the time, it's best to watch it as a near 10-hour feature production. What a horrible time the original TV viewers must have had waiting for the next installment. Each episode has multiple plots so it is impossible to break down the episodes into short summaries. And with carryover from one episode to another, it's more like moving to Lark Rise or Candleford and living with the good people (and the bad). A delightful scenic experience even Disney has never matched.Ah, but the folks you will meet. Dr. Seuss eat your heart out. Queenie (Linda Bassett), an old bee keeper, is married to ole Twister (Karl Johnson) and both will make you laugh and cry, perhaps in the same scene. Pearl (Matilda Ziegler) and Ruby (Victoria Hamilton) own Pratt's General Drapers & Haberdashers. They represent the best of fashion and fitness, just ask them, as they spurn much gossip and controversy. Thomas (Mark Heap) is a postal delivery man who helps keep Christianity alive and aloud. Portly Caroline (Dawn French) a mother with her man off to sea, divides her time between frivolity and beer and would make a fine Viking helpmate. And dear, dear old housemaid Zillah (a standing O for Liz Smith), is the life and death of every party--a quirkiness totally lovable. Assistant gamekeeper Phillip and melodean-playing Alfie vie for Laura's affection, while her ma, Emma (Claudie Blakley), and pa, Robert (Brendan Coyle) try in vain to keep sanity to the comings and goings of life from "Lark Rise to Candleford."Oh and more, locations and sets to die for a vacation in. Costumes to dazzle, delight, and disgust, depending upon the event. Every emotion you have ever felt in your past will be repeated sometime throughout this English town saga. The adapted books by Flora Thompson have never been read by this reviewer, but I can't imagine them being as fine as this TV series (and I'm a book lover). A superb British cast has perfected this story.Subtitles? Yes!Bonus? "The Making of Lark Rise To Candleford"Recommendation? BUY NOW! EXPEDITE SHIPPING, it's that good.
summary: BRITISH PERIOD PERFECTION--SOMETHING FOR EVERY TYPE OF DRAMA ADDICT

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Yet another "British Invasion" series from British television. Lark Rising is a rural hamlet 8 miles (or thereabouts) away from a prosperous little town, Candleford. The story centers around Laura Timmins, eldest daughter of a stonemason in the hamlet, who is sent to work for Dorcas Lane, the Candleford postmistress. There are plenty of vivid characters, Lord Timothy, who seems to be in love with Dorcas as well as his neurotic wife Lady Adelaide. Laura's family (her father is played by the wonderful Brendan Coyle from "Downton Abbey"--he played Mr. Bates the valet), and the rest of the ensemble cast is delightful.The only weak spot is Laura herself. Either it's the script or actress Olivia Hallinan, but this ingenue role is bland and boring in comparison to all the wonderful characters surrounding her. It's not easy to play the "straight man" and I'm afraid Miss Hallinan doesn't have the acting chops to stand up to such a crowd with a difficult role to play. I go to sleep when she's on the screen. However, that doesn't stop me from enjoying yet another Victorian era costume drama from Great Britain. And it's a Prime offering, meaning Prime subscribers can download it with no additional charge. Good stuff.
summary: British "Invasion" period drama with plenty of comedy & drama
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Lark Rise to Candleford Season 1 was a worthwhile find.  The characters are so well developed and the pleasant, amusing, gentle climate of the village as well as the town is refreshing.  I will watch all the seasons and then begin again!

reviewText: I would highly recommend this Series to anyone who likes family oriented television.  The characters are so well written you'd think you known them!  Very sweet.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I caught one episode of Lark Rise to Candelford on PBS and I was interested to see it because I had been recommended this series from Amazon.  After seeing just one episode, I knew I was going to have to buy the complete first season.  I was hooked.  The story follows one young woman Laura Timmins as she leaves the small rural village community of Lark Rise and heads to the more bustling larger community of Candelford to work for her cousin Dorcus Lane who is the Post Mistress at the Post Office in Candelford.  Through these two characters we see some of the more pressing social issues of the day.  This series deals with everything from woman's issues, to better working conditions, liberal vs.conservative ideas. The main theme of the series is the growing upheaval of the rural communities going through a period of urban expansion. You can find almost any emotional issue in this series, from first love, unrequited love, and the power of friendship.  Julia Sawalha plays Dorcus Lane and I think she does a fantastic job in this series, she captures Miss Lane's spirit, fierce independence and warm heart.  Her performance is well worth watching.  If you enjoy period dramas, this is another excellent one by BBC and a great addition to an collection, I personally will be buying Season Two and Three and looking forward to devouring them.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: A great period piece taking place in England around the turn of the 18 century.  No sex, no violence, no killing.  A wholesome look at everyday life.

reviewText: A sweet yet engrossing little British television show with a really seriously top notch cast. A mite bit sacharine at times, but absolutely well worth watching nonetheless. And -- as anyone who has watched the show will empathise with -- I loved tuning in to see what the postmistress's 'one weakness' would be each episode!Highly recommended, especially for fans of Cranford, and for anyone who loves to see stars from such shows as Ab Fab and Coupling, to name but a few.I'm glad to see series 2 has been made, and I for one can't wait to see it.
summary: Fans of good British TV shows rejoice!
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: The series doesn't exactly follow the text, which reads like a documentary or commentary or diary/journal (which, of course, it was).I read it first in 1981 and reread it after watching the series a month ago.  The series is lively, romantic, character driven, and fun--I fell in love with it.  The book doesn't exactly plod, but the 1800s in the English countryside described by Thompson were far from glamorous.  The series focuses on the second part of the book and Laura's move from Lark Rise to Candelford, whereas the book's main focus is the folk of Lark Rise, basically because Thompson didn't want their way of life to be forgotten in the mad rush to modernize and move on into the industrial age.  If you can't read the text, be sure to watch the series as it attempts to cover the entire gamut from poverty to romance and from folklore to Paris fashion in the England of Laura's youth.  The characters are well drawn, and I don't think you'll soon forget them.  If you're looking for a photocopy of the book, however, you'll not get one.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Really enjoyed this show.  I love the innocence and the the great writing. I can watch with my children and not worry about what they will take away from it.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

The story lines are very creative and show a lot of imagination. The settings are just right. The characters are believeable and lovable and hateable. Nice job.

reviewText: PBS needs to snap up this gem of a show - it's utterly delightful.  I cannot wait for BBC to release a US format version.If you have been dreaming of a weekly costume drama, it's here!  It exists!  Based (Well, perhaps loosely) on the actual diary of the "main" character, Laura, Lark Rise to Candleford is a gentle series about rural vs. town life in the late 1800's.Laura is from the little hamlet, Lark Rise, and gets a position at the post office in town (Candleford) working for her mother's cousin, Dorcas the postmistress.  Through her we're introduced to all the characters in the town & village and we follow them through their little adventures.If Lark Rise to Candleford was a food it would be banana pudding and vanilla wafers.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Love this series so far.  In the first episode, I thought the music was all wrong but as it went along it got better (more appropriate) and I love the story.  My husband also loves it.  We watch it together.  And he is a Ultimate Fighting kind of guy usually!
summary: Oh so nice to relax and watch
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: If you like Cranford, and that type of story, you'll love this.  I have season 2 and 3 on the way and I hope they will be just as enjoyable.  I have no reason to expect otherwise.

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: This isn't a review... it's a rave.I haven't enjoyed a series so much since Anne of Green Gables.You'll fall in love with these characters, laugh, cry and look forward to every episode.I think I'll watch it again this winter.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Lark Rise to Candleford  makes me wish I'd lived back in those days and towns.  The characters are endearing.  The stories make you both laugh and cry right along with the people you will come to love.I am currently viewing the second season and anxiously awaiting the USA release of the third.  I hate to think of this series coming to an end.If you enjoyed Cranford and The Duchess of Duke Street, you will equally enjoy Lark Rise to Candleford.  I'd give it more than 5 stars if the option was available
summary: I was born 100 years too late ...
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: The characters are interesting, and the stories are engaging - hard to stop watching! I appreciate that there is no sex, cursing, violence, etc.
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I got this because we loved Cranford and was hoping to find something longer with more modern characters that would still portray historical trends.  The minute we put it on, I knew it was going to be a major hit in our house and that we would all watch it many times.  The location, Oxfordshire, is undergoing big changes at the end of the 19C.  There is a village, Lark Rise, with many characters who are moving to the bigger city, Candleford, for work.The narrator is the cousin of the woman who runs the post office, which is a private enterprise of great social importance for the village.  The owner is a remarkable woman - one of those protean social hub types - who meddles in the affairs of others but is also stunningly clever and competent.  She is a spinster, but has much history in the town, including a youthful love affair with the current squire.  But there are many other vivid characters, including an angry moralist, a drunkard whose husband is always on voyage and yet she keeps having children, a stolidly eccentric delivery man, and two sisters who run the tailor shop and are almost always identically dressed.  Each character has much history behind them, which is slowly revealed during the season.This is a wonderful achievement and a treat for the eyes, for the mind, for humor's sake.  We will watch all 4 seasons.  Recommended with the greatest enthusiasm.
summary: an outstanding continuing period drama, meets BBC standards
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: My mom recommended this to me and said I'd love it since I love pretty much any BBC drama. She was right!! My husband and I watched the whole season and didn't want to stop! We're in our late 20's and we laughed and cried together while watching it. I was surprised my husband liked it so much. The stories and characters are so full of love. It has wonderful lessons and morals, it's a perfect family show. We had his parents watch it and they loved it just as much as we do! We've only seen the first season but I can't wait to watch the second one. I hope there will be many more seasons to come. The acting is wonderful and the sets are fabulous! LOVE IT!!!
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: Excellent production.  Good story lines, all the characters are interesting.  You never want it to end.  I have seen the entire series at least 4 times.  Top notch entertainment.  I tell everyone to watch it.

reviewText: This is such a cute show; I got hooked on it after the first episode.  Dawn French's character is truly hilarious.Still, it is a bit....well.....SLLOOOOOWWWW......so make sure you have plenty of time to watch it.  Enjoy!

Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I had to write a review since I just finished watching the first season of this wonderful series. A lot of people have written regarding what this BBC period drama is about. I won't go into particulars, but I just want to say that I truly enjoyed this series. It so well made. The costumes, the casting, the little things were all there. You felt like you were a part of both communities while you watched it. You cared for the characters like they were your friends. This is great TV. There needs to be more of this type of programming on American television. If you are thinking of buying this series, do it, you will not be disappointed!!
summary: Characters that feel like old friends
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I've just discovered Lark Rise to Candleford and have fallen in love with it, but my review is, specifically, for the instant TV version of the show.  I'm watching the first episode again, after having watched it on YouTube on my phone, and I've discovered at least two parts of the first episode that have been cut out.  While they don't necessarily pertain to the story, I'm frustrated that I spent money on an incomplete television show and am wondering why Amazon would offer edited versions.
summary: 5 Stars for the Show, 1 for the Version
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: This is a wonderful series on BBC in England, based on Flora Thompson autobiographical trilogy "Lark Rise to Candleford".  Those of us in the USA would love to see it available in a DVD format that we may watch, again and again. It can easily be compared to an English village version of Little House on the Prairie or Anne of Green Gables series; both beloved classics. Crossing our fingers!
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais

reviewText: I have been waiting for this series to be released here in the United States, and watched it within two days. I have to admit that I have yet to read the book (of the same name) by Flora Thompson that this series is based on (I plan to do so soon). The book is said to be semi-autobiographical but I can't really comment on how faithful the series is to the book since I've yet to read it. My review as such will be confined to the BBC drama.The story follows the lives of the inhabitants of the poor, sleepy hamlet of Lark Rise and the more affluent and snooty inhabitants of Candleford during the last decades of the 19th century (sometime in the 1880s I believe). The central character Laura Timmins (Olivia Hallinan) is a young girl from Lark Rise who is sent by her parents to work as an assistant to the postmistress, the capable and sensible Dorcas Lane (a brilliant Julia Sawalha). Initially Laura balks at the more restrained and formal way of life in Candleford, and is humiliated by the way some of the town's more snobbish inhabitants (such as the Pratt sisters, Pearl and Ruby, credibly portrayed by Matilda Ziegler and Victoria Hamilton) look down upon her, but she gradually finds satisfaction and a measure of happiness in her job and new surroundings, and comes to develop a true understanding of the inhabitants of both Lark Rise and Candleford, in all their complexities. Julia Sawalha is amazing in her role as the kind postmistress who acts as a sort of mentor to young Laura, and whose own life seems deceptively straightforward, despite some undercurrents, brought on by her close friendship with town squire, Sir Timothy Midwinter (Ben Miles) who is married to a city girl,the cool and composed Lady Adelaide (Olivia Grant).To delve too much into the plot would detract from the viewer's pleasure, and so all I will say is that this excellent series has everything to recommend it - a wonderful score, beautiful cinematography of the lush English countryside, and plenty of human drama, dealing with social issues, marital strife, forbidden desires, love across the different social classes,friendship, and lots of good old-fashioned humor.The ensemble cast is excellent and a delight to watch, engaging viewer's interest from the first episode till the last of the season, and I was sorry to see it come to an end. Luckily for fans, there isLark Rise to Candleford: The Complete Season Two, andLark Rise to Candleford: Season Three.
summary: Another stellar period drama from BBC
Title: Lark Rise To Candleford - Series 1 anglais
